newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Iraq could export up to 1.6 million bpd - MEES.
newsitem.headline: Iraq could export up to 1.6 million bpd - MEES.

text.p: Iraq can export up to 1.6 million barrels per day (bpd) on surge capacity but even this made it difficult for Iraq to export $1 billion of its oil under the second-stage of the United Nations oil-for-food deal, the Middle East Economic Survey (MEES) reported on Monday.
This export capacity questioned whether Iraq could export $1 billion of its oil in the window available under the United Nations oil-for-aid deal if exports started in early August.
"Iraq can export around 1.3 million bpd under normal circumstances and approximately 1.5-1.6 million bpd with a surge capacity for a short period," MEES reported.
"These figures would not allow SOMO (State Oil Marketing Organisation) to meet the $1 billion target by 6 September," the Cyprus-based newsletter reported.
"In effect, the Iraqi oil marketing authority would have a window of only five weeks to sell $1 billion worth of oil."
Weaker oil prices would mean that Iraq would have to export even more oil to make the $1 billion mark, MEES reported.

Western diplomats said last week that Iraq would have about 40 days in which to sell around $1 billion of oil or more than 1.5 million bpd at current prices assuming that oil sales do not begin again until the last week of July.

SOMO had not made any commitments to its customers regarding volume for the second 180-day period of the U.N. plan which was due to come into effect on June 8 but was delayed by disagreement over the aid distribution plan.
Iraq sold about 660,000 bpd during the first term of the U.N. monitored deal to reach a target of $2 billion to buy food and other humanitarian goods.
